subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] QS-SAMPA: a proposed format for plain-text Quickscript
msgSnippet: ... You could create an escape sequence for the namer dot. def *{ char96} so you can write ``mY nem z *pQl! AFAIK * is not already in use in TeX. Else you
messageBody:
Paul Tremblay skrev:
> Ted Larson Freeman wrote:
>>
>> Couldn't that be handled with a TeX escape sequence or
>> something? In


> The backquote (`) is used as a shorthand for smart
> (curly) quotes:
>
> ``My heart leaps up when I behold a rainbow in the sky.''
>
> ``mY hArt lipz yp W Y bihOld y renbo In D skY.''
>
> If you have to escape the backquote, you lose the purpose
> of using it. How often do we really use the backslash when
> writing QS?

You could create an escape sequence for the namer dot.

\def\*{\char96}

so you can write

``mY nem z \*pQl!''

AFAIK \* is not already in use in TeX. Else you can use \n
``my nem z \n pQl!'' although that looks much less elegant.

The namer dot is not used *that* often after all --
personally I tend to use it at the first occurrence of a
name but not afterwards. After all most scripts on this
planet (Arabic, Hebrew, Devanagari, Korean, Mongolian,
Chinese...) get along just fine with no capital letters or
equivalent indicators.

/BP 8^)>
--
Benct Philip Jonsson -- melroch atte melroch dotte se
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
No man forgets his original trade: the rights of
nations and of kings sink into questions of grammar,
if grammarians discuss them.
-Dr. Samuel Johnson (1707 - 1784)
